subject: Tooling feedback please: JUnit @Test, @RunWith etc annotations as meta-annotations proposal

messageBody:
I'm currently pursuing a number of proposal to enhance the DRYness and
clarity of JUnit based tests.

One valuable improvement in this area would be to allow common
annotations to be specified and documented in one place as meta-annotations.

For example, the @Category annotation can be applied to classes or test
methods to mark the suite or test as belonging to one or more categories.

Without meta-annotations, you can end up with something like:

@Category(SmokeTests.class, PerformanceTests.class)
public class SomeTests {
}

and

public class SomePerformanceTests {
@Test(timeout=100)
@Category(PerformanceTests.class)
public void a() {}
}

or, for Spring users, you get:

@RunWith(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.class)
@ContextConfiguration("classpath:/repositoryMocks.xml,
classpath:/service-context.xml")
@TransactionConfiguration(defaultRollback=true)
public class UserAccountServiceTests {
@Test(timeout=1000)
@Transaction(readOnly=true)
public void failedLoginShouldNotModifyAnything() { ...}
}

With meta-annotations:

/**
* Description of the general approach to service layer test and why
these specific contexts are used
*/
@Documented
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
@Target(ElementType.TYPE)
@RunWith(SpringJUnit4ClassRunner.class)
@ContextConfiguration("classpath:/repositoryMocks.xml,
classpath:/service-context.xml")
@TransactionConfiguration(defaultRollback=true)
public @interface ServiceLayerTests { }

/**
* This is used to test user interactions where services can be running
against read-only repository slaves... etc.
* The default timeout is according to our quality of service
requirements...etc.
*/
@Documented
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
@Target(ElementType.METHOD)
public @interface ServiceLayerTests { }


@ServiceLayerTests
public class UserAccountServiceTests {
@ReadOnlyUserInteractionTest
public void failedLoginShouldNotModifyAnything() { ...}
}



As shown, the ability to allow JUnit annotations to be specified as
meta-annotations adds a big win to development teams working on large
projects where common approaches and centralised documentation will benefit.


With changes as proposed in
https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/194, JUnit can easily be made
to recognise meta-annotations.

For those of you who work on tools based on JUnit, it would be great to
get some feedback on this, as you may be looking for the @Test etc
annotations yourself, but not as meta-annotations.
